data.name: Exotic numeral systems
data.description:
We all know every computer's favourite numeral system - the binary. Most of us probably heard of hexadecimal and octal as well. But how about some of their more exotic cousins?

In this kata your task is to write a function called `represent` that, given an integer `n` and another integer `base`, returns a string representation of `n` in a positional numeral system with base, um, `base`.

Examples:
```python
represent(8, 2) == '1000'
represent(24, 3) == '220'
represent(12345, 13) == '5808'
represent(41526331, 30) == '1l80b1'
```

If you are unsure how the positional systems exactly work, go ahead and check the wiki article - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numeral_system.

Be prepared for  `0 <= n <= 10^6` and `2 <= base <= 62`.

An important thing to mention is what order of symbols will we consider once we are beyond the realm of usual decimal representation. It's quite simple:

digits (0-9) < lowercase letters (a-z) < uppercase letters (A-Z)

Which gives us 62 different symbols per position (hence the upper limit of `base`).
